ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: See comments below.
The course was very valuable and the work very targeted and focused, even though it is quite demanding as a course.
Homework was so hard but it was very helpful to understand GIS overall.

I know that, ultimately, I learned quite a bit from this class. Having absolutely no GIS or mapping background, and minimal computer background outside of the standard Microsoft Office packages and Adobe Suites, I definitely had a hard time understanding what I was doing most of the time. I have also not yet taken a statistics course. This class taught me how to use tools in a GIS toolbox, but I definitely still feel fairly confused about what, precisely, the tools are telling me. Dana gave us ample opportunity to work with other students, which, given my schedule, I didn't take full advantage of. He also gave us opportunities to ask questions and trouble shoot. I, however, felt perpetually behind and though I knew I was confused, I was never quite sure of how I should articulate my confusion. Meaning, I knew there were things that I didn't understand, but I didn't know where to begin asking. My questions weren't so much how to perform a task, but how to interpret the task that I am performing. Without completely understanding the numbers or the math, it is difficult to know what operations are best to carry out.I spent more time working on projects for this course than any other course. I have never invested so much time and achieved such mediocre outcomes.
Very interesting class, both conceptually as well as practically.

I took GIS mostly for my own interest, and not really because it fits with my professional goals. I'm glad I did though. I'll never be the technician in charge of GIS for work, but I know I'll be glad to know its capabilities, so I'll know how to ask the pros for just the kind of spacial analysis I want.
Learning a tool that I can apply in future work projects.
Learning how to use GIS.
very useful
The Professor is absolueteltborganized, cares, and ensures that students get the information they want and need.

Dana is a great teacher, but focuses more on the conceptual basis for GIS and raster thinking than on the function of the ArcGIS software. I learned a lot about thinking analytically for solving complex problems.
Dana does a fantastic job explaining somewhat complicated concepts.
You learn to effectively and efficiently use a very important tool.

(1) This course provides an in depth understanding of raster graphics manipulation in GIS. While time consuming, the exercises truly leave the student feeling competent, and able to explore skills on their own.(2) The instructor is methodical, and takes appropriate conceptual leaps. This allows for optimal skill development, where you are challenged but not lost.(3) The instructor is very responsive to any inquiries.(4) This course is as much about conceptual brain gymnastics as it is practical GIS use. The conceptual skills really train you to think outside the box.(5) The final assignment/project was built into the last four weeks of class. This was a brilliant model for everyone, I think, in that we turned in work on the last day, and had no further obligations (assuming you were caught up). This allowed time for all of the other classes that had more traditional schedules.
Learning to think in new conceptual was ways. Also, the instructor was great.
The instructor and his ability to explain concepts very clearly. His class notes were very detailed and the professor was usually always available for help.
Professor's quick response and well designed problem set.

The professor was very clear about his subject in the class that it made it easy for me to learn the concepts.The professor tried using different examples to make the students understand the concepts.
Involves a lot of work, in which most of the learning are happening.
The very expressive way in which the instructor conveys concepts.
Dana Tomlin is a master of his art and an excellent pedagog.
Dana is breathtakingly knowledgeable, and incredibly adept at communicating obscure spatial theory.
You can get the idea of how to use ArcGIS.
The best thing about the course is learning skill. Learning GIS is a very good skill and it is used in every field. I liked the way Professor taught us this course.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I didn't' enjoy the homework where we had to deal with others models. It required extensive time to fix others mistakes, instead of focusing on developing and honing new skills.
workingload is a little bit heavy
Nothing. The course is designed perfectly, really.

I think it would be great if Dana and Stacey team-taught this class, so that rather than meeting once a week for 3 hours, it met twice a week, with one session taught by Dana and once session taught by Stacey, who is much better at showing step-by-step how the various software tools work. Alternatively, having an established Lab session to accompany the 3 hour lecture, led by either Dana, Stacey, or a TA, would help immensely. While TA office hours are great, I think that a lot could be gained by having a structured instruction time with the software- and students would learn as much from having that time than from puzzling through things blindly on their own.In addition, I think it would be great if the course materials (online handouts) could be printed and bound as a text book. I spent more time puzzling through the names of handouts looking for the right material than was necessary- if it was in printed form, or even in one, searchable electronic form- it would make life a lot easier.
Nothing really.

My only complaint is that the professor, with his busy teaching schedule at different schools, is never present in person to work through technical challenges. While prompt and thorough when addressing email inquiries, I do wish he was present on campus for some time each week, whether to talk about assignments or discuss outside research. That said, Stacey Maples in the map department is always on campus if professor Tomlin is not, and between the two of them and the TA, help is only a short way off.
The pace can sometimes be overwhelming.
None
Would have liked instruction on how to get data from online sources or "clean up" our own data.
requirements and instructions of the homework were not so clear and often got me confused.

I think it would be useful to have more opportunities for class DISCUSSION or CRITIQUE. I know there may not be a lot of time in the way that the class is structured, but I think I would learn more if I/other students were made to explain (verbally) the steps that they took in order to carry out an assignment. While it's valuable to see the steps that someone else took to address a problem, I think it is more helpful to discuss the train of thought that brought them to that conclusion. Peer review is useful in many ways and may command students to bemore thoughtful in the steps that they take as well as in the manner in which material is presented. Perhaps a two hour lecture and an hour for group review?
Bowers auditorium is a terrible classroom.
Nothing. Very well designed course.
Hmmm... More TAs so that there are more pros around to help.

There were confusions about the assignments in the last few weeks of the class. The assignment curriculum can be developed more concretely in advance. Also, the assignment description was often too brief and confusing.
The only thing I would like to suggest is that the course should design a final project that is of student's interest.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Excellent at the beginning of the semester, minimal at the end.
Very available, very helpful.

Dana was Very accessible by email, at any time of day, any day of the week.Anobha was also very accessible and flexible with her office hours in the computer lab at the beginning of the semester. However, she was unavailable (away from campus?) from Spring Break onwards, so we no longer had someone to ask questions in person - this was especially tough at the end of the semester as the homework assignments got longer and more complex. Anobha was fantastic, approachable, and very knowledgeable, but in the future, it would be better to have a TA who was going to be available for the full semester.
a lot

The instructor was very available electronically, which is great but only so helpful when you are puzzling through the mysteries of ArcGIS. Having in-person office time, as Dana started to do toward the end of the semester by showing up in the Sage computer lab before class time- would be far more helpful.The TA office hours were helpful, but she was gone for 2 or 3 weeks right when our assignments were getting more difficult- which was not helpful.
I only contacted the instructor (via email). He responds quickly and with helpful responses
I used the TA on a couple of occasions, and on both she did an excellent job of providing hints, but challenging me to think through the problems on my own.
Very helpful
The professor was very quick in responding questions via emails. The TA was very punctual during the TA hours and very helpful.
Anohba was really helpful and always available.
They responses very fast.
The TA seemed available and willing to help. I was never quite sure of what my questions were, though, and felt that I needed to find a tutor more than a TA.
Very responsive when needed.
Excellent. No complaints.

Fantastic email (and some in-person) responses from Dana outside of class, and ditto from the TA when I could make it to office hours. But more TA hours would be incredibly helpful - for a class this size and of this complexity, having 3 or 4 TAs worth of office hours would make a world of difference.
The instructor is very responsive, he responds to concerns of studnets over email within a day. TA is available to help during office hours.
The TA was sometimes available during office hours but never seemed to be completely available for helping us.
It was very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This was a very interesting and effective way to use GIS. I can't imagine knowing this program won't influence my career opportunities.
useful

This course is an essential complement to anyone who has taken the vector-based GIS course, and who wishes to employ GIS in the workplace. This class provided a suite of skills for practical application in my research, and in future employment. I took this course after the vector course, and would recommend that progression.
It's a technical skill that I want to have but it not directly pertinent to my concentration.
This class provides a very useful set of skills that will help me as I look for jobs. I focused in natural resource management so knowing GIS is essential.
GIS plays a significant role in career qualification. It was a great experience to learn about GIS and understand.
This course is very valuable to my program.

I'm sure it will fit in somewhere. If nothing else, I understand how to read and present basic GIS material. I might not tell someone how to reach a certain point or perform an operation, but I can communicate, on a basic level, with someone else who knows the program well enough to carry out an operation for me.

Though not sure on what to do with it, GIS is a good skill to have, and the class has definitely made me think more about spatial aspects of problems that at first glance do not seem to have any or as many.
Connects with previous introduction to GIS, with spatial statistics class, and with my masters project - wind mapping
Explained in #11.

It fits greatly, because I am working on a geographically referenced problems regarding land uses. GIS skills are very helpful for developing climate change estimates, and estimating its economic impacts, etc. I will also be applying GIS skills in my summer internship.
The course does fits very much in my program. I am doing a summer research that requires me to use GIS and do GIS modeling. It is very appropriate for my program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To obtain marketable skills for my chosen career path.
Directly applicable to my future work.
To learn how to use GIS.
To supplement the vector-based GIS fall class.
build necessary software skills
I took Professor Tomlin's first corse, and he is amazing! I wanted to learn everything possible from him.
To learn how to use ArcMap.
To continue to develop GIS skills. I wanted to feel comfortable enough with the program to work on my own, and offer a marketable skill to employers.
I wanted to learn this technical skill and how to think in strategic ways.
I felt the need to develop a tangible set of skills.
To learn GIS raster so that I can use it in my work later.
To challenge myself and to add a tool to my toolbox.
I thought GIS is a useful skill to have.
Many reasons
Again, see #11.
GIS skills were crucial to my academic/professional interests.
Because I consider mapping capabilities to be essential for people who wish to manage large tracks of land and monitor resource/waste/water movement.
I took this course because I wanted to build my skill while I am here. I took this course because I need this for my research.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
yes.
Yes.
Very much!
Yes!
yes
Absolutely and then some!
Yes, and exceeded.
The course met my expectations for learning how to effectively use ArcMap.
Absolutely. This may very well be the best class during my time at FES. I learned more skills than I knew existed, and am coming away feeling competent enough to continue on my own.
Yes
Yes
Much harder that I thought but I learned more than I thought.
Yes it did.
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yep!

yes, now I feel comfortable using GIS. I don't remember all the exact tools, but feel comfident that I can find a way to achieve any GIS-related tasks by reviewing class notes, searching for help on web, and going through trials and errors.
I did my best trying to learn as many tool as possible. I think I have been able to learn the tools Professor taught us.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Yes.
Yes.
Yes!
yes
Absolutely!
Yes.
Yes.
Yes
Yes
It was very helpful. GIS will definitely help me better manage forest.
Yes.
Time still needs to tell.
Yes
Yep! Even better too, because now I have Dana's explanatory handouts, effectively a GIS textbook.
yes
Yes and no. Yes because I learned to use the software and no because I would have liked more feedback on the weekly assignments.
Yes I did get what I had expected.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: learn from each other

I did not work in a formal group, but often brainstormed with another student or two. Most of the assignments must be done independently, but often, the major challenge is not manipulating ArcGIS, so much as understanding how to approach the problem. In this light, I occasionally worked with others to make sure we all understood how we should be thinking about the problem, and what some possible techniques that we might use, were.
It was done so that we could collaborate over the Internet to better fit our schedules; and letting us put our heads together was useful too.
Working in a small group of two was much better than working in a big group of 5 students in terms of communication.
It was very useful
GIS doesn't seem to be best tool to work in a team due to technical issues i.e. difficulties of sharing files and access to system.
I don't think pairs work is useful... Actually GIS homework is very personal.

Disadvantages: It's hard to work with and around everyone's scheduleAdvantages: Not being stuck inside of your own process and having to explain to someone what you are doing(out loud) is immensely helpful. Everyone is on a bit of a different level, though, and I felt a bit too far behind to work with those that were really excelling, and at the same time, frustrated by working with people that understood less than I did.
N/A
INVALUABLE. The more heads the better when it comes to GIS, from bouncing ideas off each other to the moral support when it gets frustrating.

Working on group is much more fun and I learn a lot more, because each person has a different way of approaching the same problem. It is very helpful to compare the approaches and choosing the most effective one.
It was very complicated to coordinate a time when we could all work on it also because we were constrained to the computer lab.
Working in group as well as doing our assignments in group was always very helpful and informative.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Its well worth the time required in out of class assignments
Start the homework early.
Budget enough time, start early on assignments.
Take it, and take vector as well if you can. However, if you can only take one, take this spring raster class.
spend as much time as you could
Attend classes and work in class along with his presentation. He is a great teacher and vet caring!
Start the homework early, and go to office hours. Also, take Stacey Maples' GIS workshops. They will reveal some small tips and tricks that will make life easier.

Start the homework assignments early why the material is still fresh in your head. Often it makes sense to think about the assignments and your plan of attack before actually sitting down at the computer.
I would definitely recommend this course for those who want or need to learn GIS. However, the course moves very quickly, so don't fall behind.

(1) Prepare for a significant time commitment, but know that it is well worth it!(2) Keep a list of questions in a word document as you do each assignment. Bring them up at the beginning of the next class.(3) Do each assignment immediately after class. This provides the easiest transition to working on one's own, and for, provided good reinforcement.(4) The lab computers work better than even a new mac with book camp.(5) Use an external hard drive for your assignments, since some of the data takes up a bit of space.(6) This really is a wonderful course. Very thorough, with the exception of Python, and excellent in both physical and intellectual development.(7) I conducted a time tracking project all term, to assist other students in planning their lives. This course took me 250:55. In many cases, I did an excessive amount of work, relative to what was needed. With 106 days in the semester between the week of the first class and the week of the last class, that is about 15+ weeks including spring break. That equates to about 16.5 hours each week. Again, this figure includes the spring break weeks, but resulted in no work beyond the last class.
I would say budget your time accordingly; the workload is hard during the majority of the semester but it pays off because there is no final exam at the end.
Start work early, definitely make use of professor Tomlin's expertise.
Try to follow all assignments that professor gives and try to spend average of 10 hours per week to digest all class materials. You will deserve it.
I will highly recommend them to take this course.
Try to go to sessions with Stace Maples. Work in the lab when the TA is there. Ask questions.
Start doing your homework earlier than a day ahead, and do it with other people.
Absolutely essential skill set for environmental scientists. Dana is a fantastic resource, make use of him while you can!
Find a teammate or two and enjoy the homeworks.
take the homework assignments seriously and have fun with it, the work is for you to learn the techiniques.
Spend at least two entire afternoons devoted to the weekly homework, preferably the day of the class.
If you are interested in learning GIS, you should take this course.
